# Styling plots

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span>Save plot as <highm>gg</highm> object.</span></li>
  <li class="m2"><span>Use existing <highm>theme_*()</highm> presets.</span></li>
  <li class="m3"><span>Customize details using <highm>theme()</highm>.</span></li>
  <li class="m4"><span>Adjust dimensions using <highm>scale_*()</highm>.</span></li>
  <li class="m5"><span>Add an notion using <highm>labs()</highm>.</span></li>
  <li class="m6"><span>Write your plot as a <highm>.pdf</highm> or <highm>.png</highm>.</span></li>
</ul>

]


.pull-right45[


<br>

```{r, fig.width=6,fig.height=7, echo=F}
basel %>%
  arrange(year, income_median) %>% 
  mutate(quarter = as_factor(quarter)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = income_median, col = quarter)) +
  geom_line() + geom_point() +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Median income",
       title = "Inequality in Basel", 
       subtitle = "Income development by quarter from 2001 to 2017",
       caption = "Source: Open Data Basel Stadt") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 7)) +
  scale_color_viridis_d()
```
]

# The <mono>gg</mono> object

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span>The output of <mono>ggplot()</mono> can be stored in an <mono>gg</mono> object.</span></li>
  <li class="m2"><span>The <mono>gg</mono> object can be expanded using <mono>+</mono> and the plot can be generated by a simple print.</span></li>
</ul>

<br>

```{r}
# store plot as object
my_plot <- ggplot(basel, 
                 aes(x = year, 
                 y = income_median, 
                 col = quarter)) +
  geom_line() + 
  geom_point()
```

]

.pull-right45[

<br>

```{r, fig.width=6,fig.height=6, echo=T}
my_plot 
```

]

# `theme()`

.pull-left45[

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span>With <high>96 arguments</high> <mono>theme()</mono> permits specification of all aesthetic details.</span></li>
  <li class="m2"><span>Makes uses of helper functions:</span></li>
  <ul class="level">
    <li><span><mono>element_rect()</mono> | for rectangles</span></li>
    <li><span><mono>element_line()</mono> | for lines</span></li>
    <li><span><mono>element_text()</mono> | for text</span></li>
    <li><span><mono>element_blank()</mono> | for removals</span></li>
  </ul>
</ul>

<br>

```{r, eval = F}
# Using theme
my_plot + 
  theme(argument = element_*(), 
        argument = element_*(),
        ...)
```

# `theme`

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span><mono>theme</mono>s can be stored in an object.</span></li>
  <li class="m2"><span><mono>theme</mono> objects are not functions.</span></li>
</ul>

<br>

```{r, eval = F}
# save my theme
my_theme <- theme(
  legend.position = "bottom",
  legend.title = element_blank(),
  legend.text = element_text(size = 7))


# Add my theme
my_plot + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  my_theme

```

]


.pull-right45[

<br>

```{r, fig.width=6,fig.height=7,echo = F}
# Fixing the legend

  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 7))
```

]

# Wrangling

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span>Again, wrangling can help with plotting.</span></li>
  <li class="m2"><span>The order of discrete variables can be controlled using <highm>factors</highm>.</span></li>
</ul>

```{r, echo = F}
# change data
basel_order <- basel %>%
    
  # factor ordered by income in 2001
  arrange(year, income_median) %>% 
  mutate(quarter = as_factor(quarter))

options(tibble.width = 40)
```

```{r, eval = F}
# change data
basel_order <- basel %>%
    
  # factor ordered by income in 2001
  arrange(year, income_median) %>% 
  mutate(quarter = as_factor(quarter))

# show data
basel_order
```


]

.pull-right45[

<br><br><br>

```{r, echo = FALSE}
basel_order
```

]

.pull-left45[

# Wrangling

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span>Colors are assigned according to the <high>order of factor levels</high>.</span></li>
</ul>

```{r, eval = F}
basel_order %>%
  
  # original code
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = income_median, 
             col = quarter)) +
  geom_line() + geom_point() +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.title = element_blank(),
    legend.text = element_text(size=7)) + 
  
  # ordered implicitly
  scale_color_viridis_d()
```


]

<br>

```{r, fig.width=6,fig.height=7,echo = F}
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",

    legend.text = element_text(size=7)) +

```

# `labs()`

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span>Various annotations can be added using <mono>labs()</mono>.</span></li>
  <li class="m2"><span>Key arguments:</span></li>
  <ul class="level">
    <li><span><mono>x,y</mono> | Axes</span></li>
    <li><span><mono>title, subtitle</mono> | Title and Subtitle</high></span></li>
    <li><span><mono>caption</mono> | Caption</high></span></li>
  </ul>
</ul>

```{r, fig.width=6,fig.height=7,echo = F}
my_plot = basel %>%
  
  # sort by income and factor quarter
  arrange(year, income_median) %>% 
  mutate(quarter = as_factor(quarter)) %>% 
  
  # original code
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = income_median, col = quarter)) +
  geom_line() + geom_point() +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.title = element_blank(),
    legend.text = element_text(size=7)) + 
  scale_color_viridis_d()
```

<br>

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
my_plot +
  labs(x = "Year",
       y = "Median income",
       title = "Inequality in Basel",
       subtitle = "Income development...",
       caption = "Source: Open Data...")
```

]


.pull-right45[

<br>

```{r, fig.width=6,fig.height=7,echo = F}
my_plot +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Median income",
       title = "Inequality in Basel", 
       subtitle = "Income development by quarter from 2001 to 2017",
       caption = "Source: Open Data Basel Stadt")
```

# Aggregates


.pull-left45[

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span>To visualize aggregates and error, first generate them using <highm>dplyr</highm>.</span></li>
</ul>


```{r, eval = T, echo=F}
basel_agg <- basel %>%
  
  # get income mean in 2001
  arrange(year, quarter) %>% 
  group_by(quarter) %>% 
  mutate(inc01 = first(income_median)) %>% 
  
  # group by year and quarter
  group_by(year, 
           hi = inc01 > median(inc01)) %>% 
  summarize(income = mean(income_median)) %>% 
  
  # remove grouping
  ungroup()
```


```{r, eval = F, echo=T}

  arrange(year, quarter) %>%

  mutate(inc01 = first(income_med.)) %>%

  group_by(year, 
           hi = inc01 > median(inc01)) %>% 
  summarize(income = mean(income_med.)) %>% 
  
  # remove grouping
  ungroup()

# show data
basel_agg
```

# Error

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span>To visualize aggregates and error, first generate them using <highm>dplyr</highm>.</span></li>
</ul>


```{r, eval = F}
# confidence interval function
ci = function(x) {
  n = length(x)
  sd(x) / sqrt(n) * qt(.975, n-1)}

# new data with error
basel_agg <- basel %>%
  
  # get income mean in 2001
  arrange(year, quarter) %>% 
  group_by(quarter) %>% 
  mutate(inc01 = first(income_median)) %>% 
  
  # group by year and quarter
  group_by(year, 
           hi = inc01 > median(inc01)) %>% 
  summarize(inc_m = mean(income_median),
            inc_ci = ci(income_median)) 
```

```{r, eval = T, echo = F}
# confidence interval function
ci = function(x) {
  n = length(x)
  sd(x) / sqrt(n) * qt(.975, n-1)}

# new data with error
basel_agg <- basel %>%
  
  # get income mean in 2001
  arrange(year, quarter) %>% 
  group_by(quarter) %>% 
  mutate(inc01 = first(income_median)) %>% 
  
  # group by year and quarter
  group_by(year, 
           hi = inc01 > median(inc01)) %>% 
  summarize(inc_m = mean(income_median),
            inc_ci = ci(income_median))  %>% 
  ungroup
```

# <mono>geom_errorbar()</mono>

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span><mono>geom_errorbar()</mono> can be used to visualize <high>standard statistical error bars</high>.</span></li>
</ul>

```{r, eval = F}
basel_agg %>%
  
  # plot code
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = income, 
             col = hi, fill = hi)) +
  
  # error bar geom inserted
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = inc_m - inc_ci,
                    ymax = inc_m + inc_ci)) + 

  ...
  
```

# <mono>annotations()</mono>

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span><mono>annotate()</mono> can be used to <high>add any type of plot elements</high> (layers) using vector specification.</span></li>
</ul>

```{r, eval = F}
basel_agg %>%
  
  # plot code
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = inc_m, 
             col = hi)) +
  
  # annotate
  annotate('line', 
           x = 2008, y = c(37500,62500)) +
  annotate('text', 
           x = 2010, y = 63000, 
           label = 'Financial crisis',
           fontface = "italic") +
  
  ...
```

]

# `ggsave()`

.pull-left45[

<ul>
  <li class="m1"><span>Saves plots to the hard drive.</span></li>
  <li class="m2"><span>Key arguments:</span></li>
  <ul class="level">
    <li><span><mono>file name</mono> | File name/path</span></li>
    <li><span><mono>device</mono> | e.g., <mono>".pdf"</mono> or <mono>".png"</mono></span></li>
    <li><span><mono>path</mono> | Path to folder</span></li>
    <li><span><mono>height, width</mono> | Height, Width</span></li>
    <li><span><mono>unit</mono> | Unit for Height, Width</span></li>
    <li><span><mono>dpi</mono> | Resolution</span></li>
  </ul>
</ul>

]


.pull-right45[


```{r, eval = FALSE}
# Save as pdf
ggsave(filename = "my_plot.pdf",
       plot = my_plot,
       device = "pdf",
       path = "3_Figures",
       width = 7, 
       height = 7)

# Save as png
ggsave(filename = "my_plot.png",
       plot = my_plot,
       device = "png",
       path = "3_Figures",
       width = 7, 
       height = 7)
```

]
